column2: Such was the information of the first five minutes; the second unfolded thus much in detail--that they had driven directly to the York Hotel, ate some soup, and bespoke an early dinner, walked down to the pump-room, tasted the water, and laid out some shillings in purses and spars; thence adjourned to eat ice at a pastry-cook's, and hurrying back to the hotel, swallowed their dinner in haste, to prevent being in the dark; and then had a delightful drive back, only the moon was not up, and it rained a little, and Mr. Morland's horse was so tired he could hardly get it along.

column2: Then why do you stay away so long? replied Catherine--finding that he waited for an answer.
column3: Then why do you stay away so long? replied Catherine-finding that he waited for an answer.

column2: That is kind of you, however--kind and good-natured.	That is kind of you, however-kind and good-natured.
column3: true

column2: I shall not forget it in a hurry.
column3: I shall not forget it in a hurry.

column2: But you have more good nature and all that, than anybody living, I believe.
column3: But you have more good nature and all that, than anybody living, I believe.

column2: A monstrous deal of good nature, and it is not only good nature, but you have so much, so much of everything; and then you have such--upon my soul, I do not know anybody like you."
column3: A monstrous deal of good nature, and it is not only good nature, but you have so much, so much of everything; and then you have such-upon my soul, I do not know anybody like you."

column2: Oh! dear, there are a great many people like me, I dare say, only a great deal better.	Oh! dear, there are a great many people like me, I dare say, only a great deal better.

column2: Good morning to you."
column3: Good morning to you."

column2: But I say, Miss Morland, I shall come and pay my respects at Fullerton before it is long, if not disagreeable.
column3: But I say, Miss Morland, I shall come and pay my respects at Fullerton before it is long, if not disagreeable.

column2: Pray do.	Pray do.
column3: true

column2: My father and mother will be very glad to see you."
column3: My father and mother will be very glad to see you."

column2: And I hope--I hope, Miss Morland, you will not be sorry to see me.
column3: And I hope-I hope, Miss Morland, you will not be sorry to see me.

column2: Oh! dear, not at all.	Oh! dear, not at all.
column3: true

column2: There are very few people I am sorry to see. Company is always cheerful."
column3: There are very few people I am sorry to see. Company is always cheerful."

column2: That is just my way of thinking.	That is just my way of thinking.
column3: true

column2: Give me but a little cheerful company, let me only have the company of the people I love, let me only be where I like and with whom I like, and the devil take the rest, say I. And I am heartily glad to hear you say the same.
column3: Give me but a little cheerful company, let me only have the company of the people I love, let me only be where I like and with whom I like, and the devil take the rest, say i And I am heartily glad to hear you say the same.

column2: But I have a notion, Miss Morland, you and I think pretty much alike upon most matters."
column3: But I have a notion, Miss Morland, you and I think pretty much alike upon most matters."

column2: Perhaps we may; but it is more than I ever thought of.	Perhaps we may; but it is more than I ever thought of.
column3: true

column2: And as to most matters, to say the truth, there are not many that I know my own mind about."
column3: And as to most matters, to say the truth, there are not many that I know my own mind about."

column2: By Jove, no more do I. It is not my way to bother my brains with what does not concern me.	By Jove, no more do i It is not my way to bother my brains with what does not concern me.
column3: true

column2: My notion of things is simple enough.
column3: My notion of things is simple enough.

column2: Let me only have the girl I like, say I, with a comfortable house over my head, and what care I for all the rest?
column3: Let me only have the girl I like, say I, with a comfortable house over my head, and what care I for all the rest?

column2: Fortune is nothing.
column3: Fortune is nothing.

column2: I am sure of a good income of my own; and if she had not a penny, why, so much the better."
column3: I am sure of a good income of my own; and if she had not a penny, why, so much the better."

column2: Very true.	Very true.

column2: I think like you there.
column3: I think like you there.

column2: If there is a good fortune on one side, there can be no occasion for any on the other.
column3: If there is a good fortune on one side, there can be no occasion for any on the other.

column2: No matter which has it, so that there is enough.
column3: No matter which has it, so that there is enough.

column2: I hate the idea of one great fortune looking out for another.
column3: I hate the idea of one great fortune looking out for another.

column2: And to marry for money I think the wickedest thing in existence.
column3: And to marry for money I think the wickedest thing in existence.

column2: Good day.

column2: We shall be very glad to see you at Fullerton, whenever it is convenient." And away she went.
column3: We shall be very glad to see you at Fullerton, whenever it is convenient." And away she went.

column2: It was not in the power of all his gallantry to detain her longer.
column3: It was not in the power of all his gallantry to detain her longer.

column2: With such news to communicate, and such a visit to prepare for, her departure was not to be delayed by anything in his nature to urge; and she hurried away, leaving him to the undivided consciousness of his own happy address, and her explicit encouragement.
column3: With such news to communicate, and such a visit to prepare for, her departure was not to be delayed by anything in his nature to urge; and she hurried away, leaving him to the undivided consciousness of his own happy address, and her explicit encouragement.

column2: The agitation which she had herself experienced on first learning her brother's engagement made her expect to raise no inconsiderable emotion in Mr. and Mrs. Allen, by the communication of the wonderful event.
column3: The agitation which she had herself experienced on first learning her brother's engagement made her expect to raise no inconsiderable emotion in mr and mrs Allen, by the communication of the wonderful event.

column2: How great was her disappointment!
column3: How great was her disappointment!

column2: The important affair, which many words of preparation ushered in, had been foreseen by them both ever since her brother's arrival; and all that they felt on the occasion was comprehended in a wish for the young people's happiness, with a remark, on the gentleman's side, in favour of Isabella's beauty, and on the lady's, of her great good luck.
column3: The important affair, which many words of preparation ushered in, had been foreseen by them both ever since her brother's arrival; and all that they felt on the occasion was comprehended in a wish for the young people's happiness, with a remark, on the gentleman's side, in favour of Isabella's beauty, and on the lady's, of her great good luck.

column2: It was to Catherine the most surprising insensibility.
column3: It was to Catherine the most surprising insensibility.

column2: The disclosure, however, of the great secret of James's going to Fullerton the day before, did raise some emotion in Mrs. Allen. She could not listen to that with perfect calmness, but repeatedly regretted the necessity of its concealment, wished she could have known his intention, wished she could have seen him before he went, as she should certainly have troubled him with her best regards to his father and mother, and her kind compliments to all the Skinners.
column3: The disclosure, however, of the great secret of James's going to Fullerton the day before, did raise some emotion in mrs Allen.
